name: US Council of Muslim Organizations
mission: Facilitating, coordinating, and strengthening educational activities conducted by its member organizations.
theoryOfChange: By uniting Muslim organizations under one umbrella, USCMO leverages collective advocacy, diplomatic engagement, and civic participation to challenge systemic barriers and influence national policy.
zakatClaimEvidence: The US Council of Muslim Organizations' homepage mentions a 'DONATE' option and an 'Endowment (Waqf) Conference 2025' but does not explicitly mention 'zakat' or 'zakat donations' on its main page. There is no direct evidence in the provided search results that this specific US charity accepts zakat. (Source: https://uscmo.org/index.php/donate/)

dimension_explanations.alignment: Alignment is considered medium as the organization focuses on high-level advocacy and coordination rather than direct humanitarian relief [1]. While it provides a platform for Muslim organizational unity, the donor fit is specialized for those prioritizing systemic advocacy, and it is explicitly categorized as sadaqah-eligible [3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates a direct provision model through its coordination of National Open Mosque Day and diplomatic programs [1]. While it maintains a 100.0% program expense ratio, the overall impact score is tempered by low data confidence and a lack of third-party evidence regarding specific cost-per-beneficiary metrics [2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The US Council of Muslim Organizations serves as a national umbrella body dedicated to coordinating educational and diplomatic initiatives for the American Muslim community.
strengths: Maintains a 100.0% program expense ratio, indicating all reported expenses are directed toward its mission and programs [1]
Operates with high fundraising efficiency, reporting $0.00 spent for every $1 raised [2]
baseline_narrative.summary: The US Council of Muslim Organizations (USCMO) facilitates and strengthens educational activities through its member organizations while managing diplomatic initiatives and National Open Mosque Day [1]. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported total revenue of $632,652 to support its advocacy and community coordination efforts [2]. Donations to the council are accepted as sadaqah to support their ongoing mission and programs [3].

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize American Muslim civic representation and want to fund a lean umbrella organization that coordinates national advocacy efforts.
donor_motivations: Want to support political and diplomatic advocacy for US Muslims
Value high financial efficiency with minimal overhead
Interested in supporting a coalition of diverse Muslim organizations
giving_considerations: The organization is in a growth phase with limited external transparency ratings
Impact is measured through coordination and summits rather than direct service delivery

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a high program expense ratio but a lack of verified beneficiary data or external evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: USCMO operates on the premise that coordinating member organizations and facilitating national summits will increase the collective political and social influence of the American Muslim community.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that advocacy efforts translate into tangible policy changes or community benefits.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a national umbrella body, USCMO has significant capacity to expand its advocacy and diplomatic reach with additional funding.

peer_comparison.differentiator: USCMO maintains a <cite id="7">98.6% program ratio</cite>, which is higher than the <cite id="10">peer median of 89.1%</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="7">98.6% of its total expenses</cite> toward its mission-related programs, significantly exceeding the <cite id="10">industry standard of 75%</cite>.
USCMO reports spending <cite id="11">$0.00 for every $1 raised</cite>, indicating that donor contributions are not eroded by high solicitation costs.
The council has achieved a <cite id="6">3-year revenue CAGR of 56.8%</cite>, growing from $257,291 in 2021 to over $630,000 in 2023.

strengths_deep_dive: USCMO's financial efficiency is its primary operational strength. By maintaining a <cite id="7">100.0% program expense ratio</cite>, the council ensures that nearly every dollar donated supports its <cite id="1">diplomatic and educational coordination</cite>. This efficiency is coupled with a <cite id="12">working capital ratio of 3.4 months</cite>, providing a stable financial cushion for its advocacy operations. Furthermore, the organization's <cite id="13">independent board members comprise 75%</cite> of its leadership, meeting key governance benchmarks for oversight in the non-profit sector.
rich_narrative.summary: The US Council of Muslim Organizations (USCMO) serves as a national umbrella body dedicated to <cite id="1">coordinating educational and diplomatic initiatives</cite> for the American Muslim community. As a coalition-based entity, it focuses on <cite id="2">strengthening activities conducted by its member organizations</cite> while spearheading national programs such as <cite id="3">National Open Mosque Day</cite> and <cite id="4">National Advocacy Day</cite>. In the 2023 fiscal year, USCMO reported <cite id="5">total revenue of $632,652</cite>, representing a significant <cite id="6">3-year revenue CAGR of 56.8%</cite>. The organization operates with a lean financial model, maintaining a <cite id="7">program expense ratio of 100.0%</cite>, ensuring that the vast majority of contributions directly fund its advocacy and diplomatic summits. Beyond its member coordination, the council facilitates <cite id="8">National Leadership Summits</cite> and an <cite id="9">Annual Ramadan Iftar</cite> to foster civic engagement and political representation for Muslims across the United States. While the organization has demonstrated rapid growth in its funding base, it remains an emerging institution in terms of its formal impact reporting and third-party transparency metrics.
